title: Hurricane Dorian is set to wreak havoc on air travel — here's what you need to know about flights
text:
A dangerous tropical storm in the Caribbean strengthened Wednesday to become Hurricane Dorian.

The Category 5 hurricane was bearing down on the Bahamas on Sunday, and is expected to make landfall in the US somewhere on the Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, or North Caroline coasts as a "major hurricane" — Category 3 or stronger — by late Monday or early Tuesday, according to the National Hurricane Center.

While the storm was initially forecasted to slam into the Florida coast, shifts on Saturday suggested it would move further north, possibly remaining off the coast. However, regardless of where the storm's center makes landfall — or whether it does at all — it's likely that most of the South-East will feel effects from the storm.

Air travel is expected to be impacted, though as in many cases of severe weather, effects could ripple across the US as aircraft are repositioned or delayed because of the storm.

American, Alaska, Delta, Frontier, JetBlue, Southwest, Spirit, and United have issued travel waivers, allowing people with flights that may be directly affected to change their itineraries without a fee.

Those waivers initially applied mostly to airports in Florida and the Caribbean. As the storm's projected path shifts, it is likely that airlines will add additional waivers.

Multiple airlines also announced it would waive pet-in-cabin and baggage fees on flights from certain airports in order to help with evacuations.

On Friday afternoon Orlando Airport became the first airport to announce a closure, saying it would cease operations Monday at 2 a.m. — however, it rescinded that on Saturday afternoon, saying it planned to maintain services.

description: With Hurricane Dorian bearing down on the Bahamas on Sunday and its eventual track to the US uncertain, here's what you need to know about flights.
